item.title: Separating Concerns with Pipes & Filters
item.description: Build a pipeline using the Pipes & Filters Pattern that allows you to separate concerns (Logging, Validation, etc.) when processing a request.

item.title: It's tough being an Azure fan
item.description: Azure has never been the #1 cloud provider - that spot continues to belong to AWS, which is the category leader. However, in most people’s minds, it has been a pretty reasonable #2, and while not necessarily vastly differentiated from AWS there are enough things to write home about. However, even as a user and somewhat of a fan of the Azure technology, it is proving increasing difficult to recommend.
item.author: (Alex Hudson)

item.title: A New Dawn of Learning
item.description: Enabling individuals to maximize their potential and contributions is a key component of global prosperity and peace. Outdated educational models where formative years are devoted to obtaining a standard set of knowledge with the goal of entering lifelong employment fall short in a globally connected world where technologies, skills, and opportunities rapidly fluctuate. We need a system that allows for the rapid learning of desired skills in anticipation of, and in response to, the immediate needs of markets and individuals.

item.title: Building a Monad
item.description: We're going to build a new monad. To get there, we'll explore creating a means of tracking analytics events and start with some simple solutions that will eventually coalesce into our monad.

item.title: Guix-HPC — What’s in a package
item.description: There is no shortage of package managers. Each tool makes its own set of tradeoffs regarding speed, ease of use, customizability, and reproducibility. Guix occupies a sweet spot, providing reproducibility by design as pioneered by Nix, package customization à la Spack from the command line, the ability to create container images without hassle, and more.

item.title: A different kind of keyboard
item.description: I’ve always been attracted to chording keyboards in theory, but I lack whatever childhood musical training is required to wrap my fingers around them. So I made something else: an arpeggio keyboard. Peggi is an eight-key keyboard that fits on the back of your phone. While chording keyboards require you to press multiple keys at the same time, arpeggio keyboards only ask that you type multiple keys in sequence.

item.title: Converting between UTF-8 strings and UTF-16 strings in C++/WinRT
item.description: C++/WinRT provides a pair of functions for converting between UTF-8 strings (with code units represented as char) and UTF-16 strings (code units of wchar_t). The to_string function takes a std::wstring_view of UTF-16 code units and converts them to a UTF-8 string,
item.author: (Raymond Chen)
